bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 22 (Tuesday, February 10, 2015)][Pages H917-H918]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. DENT:H.R. 836.[[Page H918]]Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1 section 8 of the US consititution

item.title: Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.

item.title: Reducing Employer Burdens, Unleashing Innovation, and Labor Development Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Research and Technology.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

item.name: Emergency medical services and trauma care

summary.text:
Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2015

Amends the Public Health Service Act to deem a hospital or an emergency department and a physician or physician group of a hospital or emergency department to be an employee of the Public Health Service with liability protection provided by the United States for purposes of any civil action that may arise due to providing emergency and post-stabilization services on or after January 1, 2016.

bill.title: Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2015

item.title: Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2015
To improve access to emergency medical services, and for other purposes.
Health Care Safety Net Enhancement Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
